text: in this recipe I took grilled onions
shallots and garlic made them into a
relish and then put the whole thing
together as a dip with a middle-eastern
yogurt called Lebanon
this is the kind of thing that you
should make while you're already
grilling something else just throw the
skewers onto the grill and you can
practically forget about them you need
to soak your wooden skewers before you
thread them with anything when you're
grilling why because if you put on the
soaked wood on a grill they will catch
fire when you skewer these you want to
leave just a little bit of room in
between each piece you don't want to jam
them together and this helps them cook
more evenly and a little more quickly in
addition to grilling onions and shallots
I'm also gonna grill some garlic and let
me get it nice and soft and then I'm
gonna mash it into a paste which is just
gonna add this very rich flavor whenever
you're cooking dense vegetables like
onions and shallots you need to use a
combination of indirect and direct heat
direct heat gives you the charm and the
caramelization and then the indirect
heat lets them cook through before they
burn I made a little relish with the
onions and shallots at the end I added
some mint and parsley some olive oil and
lemon juice and then I added preserved
lemon they're basically pickled lemons
and they add this funky fermented flavor
that is absolutely delicious but don't
stress if you don't have them you can
leave it up the first time I tested this
dish I didn't use labneh which is a very
creamy and thick middle-eastern yogurt I
just used regular old Greek yogurt from
the supermarket and it was really good
but labna is even better because it's
richer and creamier at the very end I
sprinkled everything with sumac which is
a tart little berry that's dried ground
and it's just got a terrific tangy
flavor this is great to serve with
grilled pita bread and since you have
the grill and it's hot anyway
you might as well make something
